title: How to Make White Chocolate Rainbow Brownies

steps.headline: Double boil the chocolate chips with the butter.
steps.description: (this means heat them until melted/blended in a pot/bowl on top of another pot with boiling water in it. This keeps them off of the direct heat source so they don't burn).

steps.headline: Take them off the heat when completely melted.
steps.description: Let cool to room temperature (even a little warmer is fine). Keep mixing so you don't get a solid block of chocolate butter grossness.

steps.headline: Add 1/4 cup of sugar and two eggs and mix until smooth.
Add the flour and a generous splash of vanilla.
steps.description: If your inner child is dead, skip all of the color related steps and add some chopped nuts during this step for equally delicious, but less fun, brownies.

steps.headline: Mix n' stuff.
steps.description: No little white pockets of flour please, that's not yummy. After you're done mixing, grease an 8x8 baking pan and preheat your oven to 350.

steps.headline: Now pour 1/x of your mix into a separate bowl.
steps.description: (Where x= the amount of colors you want). Add a few drops of food color and mix until you get the shade you want.

steps.headline: Pour the first color into your pan.
steps.description: Now wash the bowl it was in and mix in another color (if you want to) and keep repeating until you have all colors poured in. THIS STEP IS NECESSARY! You don't want your colors to mix until they are in the pan.

steps.headline: If you noticed, the colors didn't mix together because the batter is too thick.
steps.description: Start mixing now, though and ugly browns are in your future.

steps.headline: If you want to make it more tie-dye, swirl with a fork QUICKLY AND SPARSELY.
steps.description: Too much mixing will mix your colors together and you'll get less pretty colors.

steps.headline: Bake at 350 for about 30 min.
steps.description: Toothpick comes out clean, slightly brown edges, etc. etc. etc. Let them cool before you cut so they maintain their shape.

text: Double boil the chocolate chips with the butter. (this means heat them until melted/blended in a pot/bowl on top of another pot with boiling water in it. This keeps them off of the direct heat source so they don't burn). Take them off the heat when completely melted. Let cool to room temperature (even a little warmer is fine). Keep mixing so you don't get a solid block of chocolate butter grossness. Add 1/4 cup of sugar and two eggs and mix until smooth.  Add the flour and a generous splash of vanilla. If your inner child is dead, skip all of the color related steps and add some chopped nuts during this step for equally delicious, but less fun, brownies. Mix n' stuff. No little white pockets of flour please, that's not yummy. After you're done mixing, grease an 8x8 baking pan and preheat your oven to 350. Now pour 1/x of your mix into a separate bowl. (Where x= the amount of colors you want). Add a few drops of food color and mix until you get the shade you want. Pour the first color into your pan. Now wash the bowl it was in and mix in another color (if you want to) and keep repeating until you have all colors poured in. THIS STEP IS NECESSARY! You don't want your colors to mix until they are in the pan. If you noticed, the colors didn't mix together because the batter is too thick. Start mixing now, though and ugly browns are in your future. If you want to make it more tie-dye, swirl with a fork QUICKLY AND SPARSELY. Too much mixing will mix your colors together and you'll get less pretty colors. Bake at 350 for about 30 min. Toothpick comes out clean, slightly brown edges, etc. etc. etc. Let them cool before you cut so they maintain their shape. Finished.
